These words, which have the literal meaning: ‘siblings whose heads are joined’, symbolize aptly the kind of relationship in which siblings stand. Another much-used phrase is: ‘ menyadi begulai pemai ’ meaning ‘siblings of common inheritance’.' [620] 'As long then, as an individual remains resident in a bilek , he (or she) is one of the group in which ownership and inheritance are vested. Indeed, it is the family as a whole that holds common tenure of the conglomeration of property and other rights which constitute ‘the bilek ’. In other words, the Iban bilek family is a corporation aggregate. Thus, no one of its members holds the right [Page 33] to disinherit another. In life the members of a bilek are parceners, and even in death each member is entitled to his share of the family estate--that last inheritance which he carries with him to the after-world. An elder looks to his children and to his grandchildren within the bilek family to care for him in his old age, and to perform conscientiously the elaborate mortuary rites which must accompany his passing from this world to the next. To the Iban these mortuary rites and the furnishing of grave goods are matters of supreme importance, and all the senior surviving members of the bilek family are expected to join in their faithful performance. As the Iban themselves phrase it: ‘As the mortuary rites are equally performed, so equally is the bilek estate inherited’ (‘ Enti blah ngelumbong, blah empu utai ’).' [621] The above information indicates that private property in land did not exist traditionally as land was attached to longhouse communities rather than individuals. The Brooke Raj was initially reluctant to more clearly regulate land ownership: 'There was a general tendency on the part of the Brooke courts to resist the demand from longhouse headmen for a clear demarcation of territorial boundaries, stemming in part from the attitudes of Charles Brooke himself. For example in 1889 Brooke settled a case ( Apai Jilani v Buya ) concerning land along the Graji stream, a tributary of the Padeh (Betong Court Book 1889:473). The land on the left bank of the Graji had already been divided in three (meaning a permanent [Page 13] division among three longhouses) but the land on the right bank had not yet been settled. The Rajah ordered: “No distinct division of land but they are to agree amongst themselves and the land to be as it were common.” The rationale for this tendency to maintain areas of disputed priority as common land between communities was apparently that it prevented one community excluding another from land for which the latter had a genuine need. It was a prime emphasis of Brooke land policy to prevent anyone from detaining land which others could use more productively. This policy was in keeping with the views of many regional leaders, who saw the importance of providing equal access to land at the inter-community level.' [622] 'However, the maintenance of shared territorial rights proved difficult in practice, indicating that the transaction costs involved in this type of arrangement were high. Whereas it was a relatively simple matter for those within one longhouse community to “agree amongst themselves” on the size and location of farms each year, for two or more communities to agree year by year on the use of common territory was not so straightforward. The difficulties were compounded when one of the communities experienced an influx of households, thereby obtaining greater use of the shared land, and this was a frequent cause of dispute. The Brooke courts muddled through this situation, laying down boundaries in some cases and establishing zones of common land in others, but the trend towards exclusive territorial rights proved inexorable and in the post-war period the convention of two or more communities sharing access to a tract of land is rarely found. Today territorial rights are still highly valued and hotly contested, with boundary disputes occasionally leading to outbreaks of violence.' [623] But longhouse territory became more clearly defined in the colonial period: 'The widespread adoption of rubber by the Saribas Iban from around 1910 helped to consolidate the notion of an exclusive longhouse territory. Firstly it had the effect of curtailing the semi-migratory tendencies which had continued during the 19th century. Sandin, reflecting on the importance of rubber, illipenut, and other perennial crops in the Saribas, observed: These trees, and accumulated family wealth, are reasons why the people are not attracted to other places. While some Iban frequently migrate, or pindah , moving always from place to place, that is not the way of the Saribas people. Our ancestors were foresightful. They saw the importance of settling properly in one place. Also there is enough land here, enough for rubber and rice (cited in Sather 1981:129,130). With the adoption of pepper in the post-war period the attachment to the longhouse territory was further increased. Despite Sandin's comment, in many communities there was not enough land for both rubber and rice, and in the 1950s and 1960s individual households had to rent wet rice land in downriver locations a day's journey or more from the longhouse. This tendency towards spatial diversification was reversed when pepper, a land-saving crop, became more profitable in the early [Page 14] 1970s and attracted farmers back to their upriver territories.' [624] 'Secondly, planting rubber, as well as providing a strong incentive to remain in one clearly defined location, also made possible the more precise identification of territorial claims. In cases where the boundary between two communities was disputed it often occurred that all the land along the disputed part of the boundary would be planted with rubber, even if it was too far from the longhouse to be economically tapped. This had the effect of more clearly identifying a community's territorial rights, as the act of planting rubber was a recent and easily remembered event compared with the felling of the original forest, and to cut down someone's rubber was a considerably more blatant offence than merely encroaching on secondary forest.' [625] However, the longhouse community largely remained the major property-holding institution of Iban society even in the post-war period: 'In the post-war period the Sarawak Government has introduced a number of planting schemes to assist smallholders in establishing cash crops, beginning with the Rubber Planting Scheme in 1956. These schemes involve the provision of planting material, fertilizer, equipment, and a cash grant to approved individuals. In recent years, however, the Department of Agriculture (which administers the schemes) has shifted its emphasis from dealing with only some individuals in a longhouse to treating the longhouse community itself as the focus of its extension program. This is in recognition that the interactions among households which gave rise to community property rights under a system of shifting cultivation also favour “community land development” in the case of perennial cash crops.' [626] 'The longhouse territory has also proved a suitable basis for the recent introduction of oil palm, a more capital intensive crop exhibiting economies of scale in post-harvest operations and hence usually requiring an estate mode of management to be viable. A significant feature of the Iban oil palm estate in the upper Lupar, administered by the Sarawak Land Consolidation and Rehabilitation Authority (SALCRA), is that the land for the scheme was acquired on a community basis, with participating longhouses each arriving at a group decision to contribute a portion of the longhouse territory. Moreover the estate is sub-divided into sectors belonging to individual communities, which have first right to employment in their own sector and can organize the way in which work will be distributed among community members. In some cases the whole community will work on the oil palm together, sharing the wages equally among all participants; in others, smaller groups will carry out the work. However in all cases the oil palm is treated as a common-property resource whose exploitation is subject to institutional regulation by the community.' [627] 'The incorporation of the longhouse community as the basic land-holding unit within a larger estate has been a major innovation by SALCRA which has reduced the transaction costs involved both in consolidating the land for planting and in the ongoing management of the estate. This institutional arrangement shows the viability of community property rights even in large-scale land development projects. Current land policy, however, appears to ignore this experience, calling as it does for the consolidation of land ownership into large private estates of several thousand hectares and for the [Page 15] regrouping of longhouse communities into centralized townships. The vehicle for this policy is the recently constituted Land Custody and Development Authority, which to date has made little progress in rural land development, arguably because it has underestimated the opportunity costs associated with dismantling the existing system of community property rights, not to mention the social and cultural dislocation likely to result from the changes envisaged.' [628] 'Summarizing the development of community property rights, it is clear that from the outset of the pioneer phase the Iban sought to convert a situation of open access into one of common or community property in which the “optimal commons” was the territory controlled by a single longhouse community. Initially community rights were vaguely defined because of the low scarcity value of primary forest and high exclusion costs. However the increased value of secondary forest in the established phase, coupled with a lowering in exclusion costs (brought about in part by the pacification of the Saribas and surrounding areas and the setting up of “native courts”), led to a much more precise definition of exclusive community property rights. The advent of perennial cash crops continued this trend by providing more incentive to remain in one location as well as a new means of identifying community claims to land. The successful recognition of community property rights within both agricultural extension programs and an estate-type development indicates the continued viability of this institutional form.' [629] The adoption of cash crops caused some changes in the 'native' property system: 'The adoption of perennial cash crops was a major factor affecting the evolution of land tenure. Like fruit trees, these crops have a long productive life. Consequently the “cropping period”, during which exclusive household rights of usufruct had always been recognized, lasted many years or even decades. Moreover the area planted was often extensive, so that exclusive rights to the trees (which was all fruit-tree tenure entailed) in effect conferred exclusive control over the tract of land on which the trees were planted. This was especially the case with rubber, with some Saribas farmers establishing quite large plantations. Even the smallest rubber holding occupied the equivalent area of one hill rice clearing and so reduced the fallow period by one year.' [630] 'Where exclusive household rights to farming land were still recognized it was a matter of individual choice to use some of this land to plant rubber, the household concerned having to weigh the benefits of rubber against the cost of having less fallow land for [Page 22] padi. However, the use of common land for rubber required careful arrangements to avoid disputes. Planting rubber effectively converted common land to privately held land and so any household not involved in rubber planting stood to lose. Moreover, there was the possibility that a household might use rubber planting simply as a device to bring more land under its exclusive control. This led to the principle that as far as possible all the co-owners of a tract of land should be included in the allocation of plots for rubber and that these should be roughly equal in size. However the risk remained that one of the co-owners would not agree to the proposed use of the land and so dispute the legitimacy of the allocation.' [631] 'The permanency of claims over land planted to cash crops has varied with the crop in question. In the case of the early coffee plantations, once these were abandoned and became overgrown they were treated as any other fallow land, and in communities with shared rights of access to such land the individual household's exclusive claim was forfeited. For example, in Ngumbang and Guntor v Saban the plaintiffs accused Saban of clearing a hill which had been the site of Guntor's coffee garden (Betong Court Book 1915:417). The Court stated [Page 23] that “. . . the coffee garden, originally planted up by Guntor has been abandoned by him [and] is now overgrown with ten or more years growth of jungle. According to custom here, he has therefore no right to restrain others from using the land.” 6 Similarly when pepper became an important crop in the post-war period some communities exercised a reversionary right over the land when the pepper itself was abandoned (though in general the small size of pepper gardens and the run-down condition of the soil gave little incentive to reclaim the land).' [632] 'However, in the case of rubber a household's exclusive rights have been allowed to exist indefinitely, even when the household leaves the community. The indefinite duration of these rights is attributable in part to the ability of rubber to survive even when not maintained or utilized, and to the lingering memory of the rubber booms when many Iban became rich. The household's claim has been strengthened, however, by the imposition of a colonial land tenure system which from the beginning of the rubber era has issued incipient titles in the form of “permits to plant” or “occupation tickets”, made out to individuals (Porter 1967). It is this factor which has overridden the principle established in the nineteenth century that on emigration a household should forfeit all claim to its farmland and tree crops. Hence the combination of a profitable and durable export crop and an institutional environment attuned to foreign principles of private property reversed the trend towards community control of land use which had emerged in relation to rice land. It has only been in recent years, with the greatly increased demand for land, that some communities have taken unilateral action to resume control over rubber land owned by emigrants, for example in the impoverished Lemanak region, where rubber trees belonging to emigrants have been cut down in order to release land for a community cocoa scheme.' [633] 'Summarizing, community regulation of land use has stressed exclusive household property rights and shared property rights in different degrees at different stages. The recognition of exclusive household rights of use and disposal in the pioneer phase, in a situation where land as such was abundant, was related to the high value placed on newly-cleared land (and on mature tree crops) and to the relative ease of negotiating and enforcing individual claims within the solidary longhouse community. The institution of the longhouse meeting ( aum ) and the principle of making all dealings clear ( terang ) to the whole community ensured that disputes over access to land were minimized. A situation which could have resulted in a scramble for the use of productive virgin land was instead carefully regulated in the long-term interests of the community. In the established phase, with uncleared and recently cleared land no longer available and mature secondary forest increasingly scarce, it became important to emphasize shared property rights to ensure an efficient and equitable pattern of land use, and hence to safeguard community [Page 24] solidarity. This involved the assertion of reversionary rights over the land and tree crops of emigrant households, the wider sharing of use rights among all the descendants of the first feller, and in many cases the pooling of all rights of disposal to form a single tract of annually reallocated farming land. Once again the longhouse meeting was the crucial institution facilitating the observance of collectively derived land-use decisions. The onset of the commercial phase required the recognition of exclusive household rights over rubber and other cash crops if there was to be any incentive to plant. However collective interests continued to be paramount in that all households had to be given a say in the allocation of land for rubber and in general gardens were of roughly equivalent size. The indefinite tenure accorded to owners of rubber gardens was a result of its durability as a crop and the imposition of alien principles of land administration. That this went against the general direction of local-level institutional change can be seen in the recent example of a community asserting reversionary rights over the land of absentee rubber owners.' [634]

♠ Usufruct ♣ present ♥ Wealth was transmitted within longhouse families (see above). We have assumed that the rights in cultivation retained by individuals residents are equivalent to usufruct rights in our own sense of the term.
♠ Exclusivity ♣ present ♥ Out-marrying residents lost rights in their natal communities (see above). We have assumed that this constitutes a form of exclusivity.
♠ Partibility ♣ absent ♥ The Iban practiced both partible and non-partible inheritance (see above and below). However, land suitable for rice cultivation was considered nonpartible.
♠ Lease ♣ absent ♥
♠ Lease Rights ♣ ♥
♠ Transfer of property ♣ present ♥ Wealth was transmitted within longhouse families. eHRAF provides a general description of the kinship system: 'The fundamental unit of Iban society is the BILEK-family, a group of five or six persons defined by kinship and affinity. Depending upon negotiations at a couple's marriage, there is an almost even chance that their children will be born into the family of either the wife or the husband. Iban families are part of a widely ramifying kinship system which developed in response to Iban mobility. The SUKU JURU and KABAN BELAYAN correspond to the kindred. The former connotes kin ties originating with one's grandparents and includes persons to the degree of first cousin. The latter is any group of people who share rights of reciprocity with an Iban, and may include nonkin and even non-Iban. More inclusive groups include "the brotherhood" and "food-sharers", made up of distant kin who would be invited to one's festivals, or whose festivals an Iban would attend. Attachment is ambilateral and descent, ambilineal. Although some Iban are capable of reconstructing genealogies up to fifteen generations in depth, such reconstructions are selective and illustrate the Iban practice of "genealogizing" so as to establish ancestral ties with strangers.' [635] 'Terms of reference are Eskimo and the terms of address, Hawaiian.' [636] 'The BILEK-family is an autonomous unit, able to join with other units of a longhouse or to detach itself. Iban become members of a family through birth, adoption, marriage, or incorporation. The family is responsible for construction of its own unit, production of its own food, and management of its own affairs. In a sample of 1,051 families, 60 percent were comprised of parents and children, 40 percent included grandparents. The family is a kin-based, corporate group, holding in trust land, sacred rice, sacred charms, ritual formulas, taboos, and heirloom gongs and jars. Traditionally, one son or daughter has remained in the BILEK to ensure continuity over time. With urban migration, and mail service making possible postal remittances, an increasing number of parents have no adult child residing in the BILEK with them.' [637] 'Rights to land are established by clearing and farming it, or by occupying it. Rights to the use of farmland are vested in the BILEK-family, and are held in perpetuity. These rights are maintained in the living memory of the residents of each longhouse. Boundaries are indicated by landforms or trees, or are marked by planting a row of bamboo. Except for the land overshadowed by the eaves of the longhouse, there is no land to which a community holds rights. With the introduction of surveys and titles to land in the early 1900s, Iban who lived closer to government centers obtained titles to their land, under which rights of individual families to land could be verified. As a result of increased population and the commercialization of land, some Iban have bought land for investment and speculation.' [638] Both sons and daughters could inherit property: 'Male and female children share equally in rights to real and other property so long as they remain members of their natal BILEK. Children who move out of the BILEK at marriage or for any other reason receive a small portion of the family estate, and in theory relinquish all rights to family land. In fact, however, they retain the right to request land for farming at the annual meeting commencing the agricultural year.' [639] 'Typically the ownership of the bilik apartment passes from parents to children. It is rare, however, for married siblings to share the same bilik , and so the apartment usually goes to just one child and his or her spouse. The remaining brothers and sisters will then marry into other bilik -families, or else establish a new bilik on their own. As will be evident from this last statement, residence patterns following marriage may be either virilocal or uxorilocal, with no particular preference being given for either one form of the other. Nor is there any formal principle - such as a rule of primogeniture - to decide which individual in a group of siblings gets to inherit the bilik in which they were born.' [640] The Iban practiced both partible and nonpartible inheritance. Nonpartible property was transmitted within senior lineages attached to a continuous longhouse community: 'It is one of the axioms of Iban adat that the padi pun of a bilek is nonpartible. What then is the solution when a family sub-divides into two separate households? Briefly it is this: the senior section retains possession of the padi pun , while the seceding section is presented with one of the sangking , which is then elevated to become its padi pun . Here, clearly, we have a criterion of crucial importance for the study of the process of bilek family formation in Iban society. The senior section of a family is always definable by the fact that its padi pun was inherited as padi pun ; while the padi pun of a seceding section is always inherited as sangking . By studying the inheritance of padi pun and sangking , therefore, it is possible to establish the main line of a family, and the various offshoots from it which have been brought about by partition.' [641] 'A second non-partible object is the batu pemanggol , or ritual whetstone, which is the centre-piece of the rites that initiate the yearly farming cycle. Each bilek family possesses one of these stones which is cherished as a magical charm of most vital importance. A few Iban families, indeed, still have whetstones upon which human victims--captives taken in war--were once sacrificed. Such stones are called batu jaum , and are immeasurably valuable in Iban estimation. To divide a batu pemanggol would be to destroy it, and so, when partition takes place, it is always retained in the ancestral bilek . The seceding section, seeking an auspicious occasion, gathers a suitable-looking stone from the river bed. With a great show of solemnity, the new stone is touched on the old and then consecrated; tutelary spirits are invoked and offerings made, and finally a pig or cock is sacrificed and the blood allowed to run on the stone's surface. This stone then becomes the batu pemanggol of the seceding section.' [642] 'When partition occurs then, the senior section of the family always retains the ancestral sacred rice and ritual whetstone. It may also happen that a bilek possesses some other unique magical or ritual object and, if this be the case, this too is retained by the senior section. With these exceptions, however, all the other property of the bilek is partible, and its apportionment is in accord with the relative size and the composition of the two sections resulting from the partition, following the general rule that siblings are parceners.' [643] Residence was ambilocal: 'Now, as already remarked, among the Iban virilocal marriage and uxorilocal marriage are equally permissible, for in Iban culture there are no beliefs or values which result in either form of marriage being given any sort of special preference. However, in all cases of permanent marriage a definite choice between the two possibilities must in the end be made, for there is no longterm system of alternate residence. Often, it is true, a newly married couple will follow first one form of domicile and then the other before finally settling down. Marrying into another apartment means permanently departing from one's natal or adoptive bilek family, and it is almost always an occasion of stress and sorrow, particularly for the parents of the seceding son or daughter. Conflicts of interest very frequently arise, but if a marriage is to endure a compromise is always reached, and, sooner or later, the couple permanently adopt either virilocal or uxorilocal residence.' [644] 'Marriage then, is an event of great moment, and particularly for the spouse who is leaving his (or her) natal apartment. Out-marriage, as we have seen, involves a radical change in jural status. It is also an occasion of psychological stress for the out-marrying spouse, since she (or he) is, in a sense, abandoning her natal family. Thus, one informant remarked that out-marriage ( ngugi ka orang ) meant ‘the casting away of one's father and mother’ (‘ itong udah buai apai indai ’). However, about 75% of Iban marriages are within the kindred, and so the stresses of out-marriage are often allayed by the fact that the out-marrying spouse is entering the household of fairly close kin.' [645] Both patrifiliation and matrifiliation were common: 'Further, membership of his (or her) natal bilek confers upon a child inheritance rights over its properties and lands, and these rights are retained as long as the individual remains a resident member. Among the Iban, then, filiation is of a special kind, for it may be either to an individual's mother's bilek or to an individual's father's bilek, but not to both at the same time. Moreover, in practice, both types of filiation occur to an approximately equal extent. We are here confronted with a fundamental principle of the Iban family system.' [646] Given the practice of ambilocal residence, inheritance rights were thus determined by residence rather than gender: 'However, should a man, upon marriage, permanently leave his natal bilek , he thereby relinquishes his parcenary rights over its estate, but acquires rights in the bilek into which he marries and settles down. The same applies to a woman who marries out of her natal apartment. An affine, then, possesses parcenary rights within the bilek of which he (or she) is a resident member.' [647] '10. Within the bilek family siblings have equivalent rights; in other words, they are parceners or co-heirs. If a sibling marries out he thereby relinquishes rights of inheritance in his natal bilek family, but acquires rights in the bilek family into which he marries. This rule applies equally to men and to women. When divorce occurs an individual returns to his or her natal bilek family and resumes rights there; but widows and widowers do not return to their natal bilek families. Thus, an analysis of 52 cases showed that there were 26 widows or widowers living as members of their natal bilek families, and 26 who were living in bilek families of which they were members by right of marriage and local residence.' [648] 'In accordance with custom, an Iban who marries into another longhouse and joins his or her spouse's family is no longer entitled to inherit ancestral lands left behind in the former longhouse area. If such an individual has no siblings living in his or her original family bilek , these lands are left under the guardianship of the Tuai Rumah, who has authority to allow other members of the longhouse to make use of them until one of the former owner's heirs can re-establish the ancestral bilek and reclaim its lands. Only lands which are officially titled can be claimed wherever the owner lives in the country; otherwise rights of use are contigent upon the family's continual residence within the longhouse where the land is located. This means that if an Iban migrates from one river to another, he will automatically loose rights to all of his temuda lands which have no official title. If he has no sibling living in the village these lands will become available for use by the people of the longhouse he has left and are subject to reapportionment by the Tuai Rumah.' [649] Both sons and daughters could initiate partition and out-marriage: '2. The bilek , with the exception of certain ritual objects, is a partible estate; and a sibling who remains in his (or her) natal bilek has the right to claim a proportionate share of the family inheritance, and set up a separate domestic unit. This is a common happening. Indeed, when two elementary families emerge [Page 8] within a bilek, partition always follows in due course. This precludes the development of joint or extended families, and nowhere in Sarawak did I encounter siblings--married and having adult children of their own--who were still living together as members of the same bilek. Again, my observations showed that partition always involves the break-up of a sibling group. When partition occurs one sibling and his (or her) family secedes from the ancestral bilek to found a new and independent household. Furthermore, this sibling is just as likely to be a man as a woman; thus, an analysis of 34 cases of partition showed that 17 founders of seceding families were males, while 17 were females. A fundamental feature of partition is that each part--after partition has occurred--is an autonomous unit in its own right, and not merely a constituent part of some wider corporate group. The partition of bilek families as it occurs in Iban society is thus a different process from segmentation as it occurs in societies based on unilineal principles.' [650] Property could also be transferred to adopted children: 'If a man and his wife, after many years of marriage, are certain that they will have no child of their own, they are likely to adopt a child in order that he or she may inherit their property after they have passed away and perpetuate their bilek family. Most couples prefer to adopt a child of their closest relatives, such as a nephew or a niece. However, if their close relatives have no child whom they are willing or able to give in adoption, the couple may adopt the child of a distant cousin or an unrelated friend.' [651] 'In order to make an adoption legal, the adopters must hold a formal ceremony called the Gawai Biru-iru, in which they publicly announce in the presences of guests, including at least two Tuai Rumah or a Penghulu, and their relatives who, otherwise, would inherit their property if they were to die childless, that the child is hereby adopted to be their own. By this proclamation the child is acknowledged as their legal heir with identical rights of inheritance, as if he or she were the couple's sole natural child. In future, if any argument arises over the disposal of the couple's property, the [Page 79] Tuai Rumah or Penghulu who were present at the Gawai Biru-iru, are responsible for safeguarding the rights of the adopted child in court. These rights, are identical whether the child is male or female.' [652] 'We have now seen that the Iban bilek family is an autonomous, corporate group, all the resident members of which--natal, adopted and affinal--hold rights over its estate. As the Iban themselves put it: ‘Whoever stands by the bilek (i.e. remains a resident member), he (or she) possesses the belongings, possesses the valuables’ (‘ Sapa tan ka bilek, iya empu utai, empu keresa ’). This was an utterance made at Rumah Nyala in 1950 during the formal discussion of the conditions which were to govern the adoption of an infant boy, and it was made by one of the men of the adopting family. It was a public pledge that as long as the adopted child elected to remain resident in their apartment he would possess identical rights of inheritance with the other members of the family. This fundamental principle of inheritance was reiterated many times during the course of the discussion--as it always is on such occasions. finally, to clinch the matter, another of the adopting party put it even more trenclantly by abruptly asserting: ‘Whoever stands by the bilek , even be he a Kayan, a Bukitan, a Punan, an Ukit, it matters not, he is the one who inherits the property’ (‘ Sapa tan ka bilek, Kayan, Pakatan, Punan, Ukit, enda iboh, tya empu keresa ’) Now, the Kayans, the Bukitans, the Punans and the Ukits are neighbouring tribes of the Rejang headwaters; all are alien, and the Kayans and Ukits, in particular, are the bitter traditional enemies of the Iban. When this is realized, the force of the utterance just quoted will be appreciated. It affirms that even an enemy and an alien, should he come to live in an Iban bilek , would, if he maintained his residence, hold equal rights of inheritance with the other members of the family. For Iban ears there could be no more emphatic avowal than this of the principle we have been considering.' [653] In-marrying affines of either sex became full members of their spouse's longhouse community: 'The position of the natal members of a bilek family in regard to inheritance is clear, for their prerogative depends on direct descent. Furthermore, as we have seen, an adopted child has conferred upon him exactly the same rights. But what of an affine whose membership dates only from the time of his (or her) marriage? By way of explanation let us consider the case of a man who marries out of his natal bilek . When such a man decides upon uxorilocal residence, and when, in the course of time, it becomes evident to all concerned that this marriage will be a lasting one, he receives from his natal bilek family a form of personal inheritance called pemai . The amount of pemai given to an out-marrying member varies considerably from case to case, for it depends largely on the degree to which the other senior members of the bilek family approve of the marriage that has been contracted. Cases do occur in which [Page 36] no pemai at all is given, while at the other extreme, planned marriages between members of wealthy families are often marked by a show of ostentation. Very commonly the pemai consists of a Chinese jar or a bronze gong, and of various smaller articles such as plates and bowls.' [654] 'The giving of this pemai is an event of signal importance, for it constitutes the final fulfilling of a man's rights of inheritance as far as his natal bilek is concerned, and it further represents the formal termination of membership of his natal (or adoptive) bilek family. Henceforward, he is a full member of his wife's bilek . His pemai , or personal inheritance, becomes part of the estate of his wife's apartment, and all his energies are now devoted to the welfare of this new family; any valuables he may acquire (as, for example, on a bejalai , or journey) are the property-- meum et tuum --of this group. In other words, when a man marries out of his own apartment and into another, he has conferred upon him full jural membership of a new corporate group, with all its attendant privileges and obligations. And the same, of course, applies to a woman.' [655] Freeman provides a general summary of the ineritance system: 'Having briefly described the composition of the bilek family and the way in which its members are recruited, we may turn to an examination of the principles governing inheritance, for these, under the Iban system of filiation, are of particular significance. Let us begin by considering the position of the natal and adopted members of the family. As has already been stressed, children become members by right of birth of either their father's or their mother's bilek --but it is always one or the other. Thus, the children of a man practising uxorilocal residence are the members of their mother's natal bilek , and of this local group alone. They have no rights of inheritance within their father's natal bilek, of which they are not resident members. Similarly, the children of a woman practising virilocal residence are members of their father's local group, and have no rights of inheritance in their mother's natal bilek . Adopted children are members of the bilek into which they have been adopted, and of this bilek only.' [656] 'The general rule for both natural and adopted children is this: as long as they remain resident members of their own bilek family, sons and daughters possess full and equal rights of inheritance over the family estate. In other words, within a bilek siblings are parceners or co-heirs. There is thus recognition of neither primogeniture nor ultimogeniture, and no differentiation [Page 32] between the sexes, nor between natural and adopted children. Instead, in matters of inheritance, siblings are equals. Their equivalence is well expressed in the phrase: ‘ menyadi tampong pala ’ which the Iban use to describe them. These words, which have the literal meaning: ‘siblings whose heads are joined’, symbolize aptly the kind of relationship in which siblings stand. Another much-used phrase is: ‘ menyadi begulai pemai ’ meaning ‘siblings of common inheritance’.' [657] 'As long then, as an individual remains resident in a bilek , he (or she) is one of the group in which ownership and inheritance are vested. Indeed, it is the family as a whole that holds common tenure of the conglomeration of property and other rights which constitute ‘the bilek ’. In other words, the Iban bilek family is a corporation aggregate. Thus, no one of its members holds the right [Page 33] to disinherit another. In life the members of a bilek are parceners, and even in death each member is entitled to his share of the family estate--that last inheritance which he carries with him to the after-world. An elder looks to his children and to his grandchildren within the bilek family to care for him in his old age, and to perform conscientiously the elaborate mortuary rites which must accompany his passing from this world to the next. To the Iban these mortuary rites and the furnishing of grave goods are matters of supreme importance, and all the senior surviving members of the bilek family are expected to join in their faithful performance. As the Iban themselves phrase it: ‘As the mortuary rites are equally performed, so equally is the bilek estate inherited’ (‘ Enti blah ngelumbong, blah empu utai ’).' [658]
♠ Use of property ♣ absent ♥ We have found no evidence for state-prescribed use of property.
♠ Property market ♣ absent ♥ We have found no evidence of a 'true' property market.

♠ Other property ownership ♣ present ♥ The following description seems to indicate that movables were private property: 'The Iban are shifting agriculturalists, whose subsistence economy has traditionally been based upon the cultivation of hill rice, or padi . Each bilik -family is an economically independent land-owning unit, whose individual members hold joint and equal rights in the family estate. Land ownership is established by the felling of primary forest, with usufructury rights maintained for as long as the bilik -family continues to exist, or at least remains resident within the longhouse community. Most bilik will also own sago and cocoa plantations, wild or semi-wild fruit trees, rubber small holdings, pepper gardens, pigs and poultry. In addition, each family will also possess its own farming equipment, tools, weapons, shotguns, canoes and other essential items needed in everyday life. In more recent times, those who are better-off will have long-boats, outboard engines and luxury items such as videos, bedding, furniture and other modern conveniences.' [659] 'Rice is also a source of disposable income - at least in those years when harvest yields exceed the annual rate of consumption. This “capital” may be exchanged for essential goods, such as salt and iron, or can alternatively be used to purchase luxury items - traditionally Chinese ceramics and local brasswares, but more recently, videos, cassette-players and other Western consumer products. Surplus rice supplies may also be put towards the sponsorship of a festival, or gawai , bringing prestige and social status to the families who do so.' [660] 'Iban women are superb weavers using the back-strap loom. Most men are skilled in the use of the piston bellows. In addition to weaving blankets and other cloths, women weave mats and baskets.' [661] 'The most important commercial activity for the largest number of Iban men has been the institutionalized BEJALAI, or journey to work for wages. In some longhouses almost all able-bodied men are away at any given time, working for a distant logging company or in the oilfields of northern Borneo. Wage-earning enabled men to buy jars, gongs, and other valuables for their families. Rubber and pepper have provided an unstable source of income, as has cocoa, a recent introduction. The attraction of salaried jobs is one of the principal reasons for Iban urban migration. Iban are employed in every major occupational category in Sarawak's cities.' [662] 'Iban collect bamboo and rattan for their own use or for sale. Natural rubber and the illipe (BASSIA sp.,the Indian butter tree) nut, which is available about every fourth year, are other important collectibles. Ironwood, sawn as logs or cut as poles, is becoming increasingly scarce.' [663]

Inheritance System

♠ partible inheritance ♣ present ♥ The Iban practiced both partible and nonpartible inheritance (see below). Land suitable for rice cultivation was considered nonpartible.
♠ patrilineal inheritance ♣ absent ♥
♠ matrilineal inheritance ♣ absent ♥
♠ primogeniture inheritance by only males ♣ absent ♥
♠ primogeniture inheritance by males and females ♣ absent ♥
♠ other inheritance practices ♣ present ♥ Wealth was transmitted within longhouse families. eHRAF provides a general description of the kinship system: 'The fundamental unit of Iban society is the BILEK-family, a group of five or six persons defined by kinship and affinity. Depending upon negotiations at a couple's marriage, there is an almost even chance that their children will be born into the family of either the wife or the husband. Iban families are part of a widely ramifying kinship system which developed in response to Iban mobility. The SUKU JURU and KABAN BELAYAN correspond to the kindred. The former connotes kin ties originating with one's grandparents and includes persons to the degree of first cousin. The latter is any group of people who share rights of reciprocity with an Iban, and may include nonkin and even non-Iban. More inclusive groups include "the brotherhood" and "food-sharers", made up of distant kin who would be invited to one's festivals, or whose festivals an Iban would attend. Attachment is ambilateral and descent, ambilineal. Although some Iban are capable of reconstructing genealogies up to fifteen generations in depth, such reconstructions are selective and illustrate the Iban practice of "genealogizing" so as to establish ancestral ties with strangers.' [664] 'Terms of reference are Eskimo and the terms of address, Hawaiian.' [665] 'The BILEK-family is an autonomous unit, able to join with other units of a longhouse or to detach itself. Iban become members of a family through birth, adoption, marriage, or incorporation. The family is responsible for construction of its own unit, production of its own food, and management of its own affairs. In a sample of 1,051 families, 60 percent were comprised of parents and children, 40 percent included grandparents. The family is a kin-based, corporate group, holding in trust land, sacred rice, sacred charms, ritual formulas, taboos, and heirloom gongs and jars. Traditionally, one son or daughter has remained in the BILEK to ensure continuity over time. With urban migration, and mail service making possible postal remittances, an increasing number of parents have no adult child residing in the BILEK with them.' [666] 'Rights to land are established by clearing and farming it, or by occupying it. Rights to the use of farmland are vested in the BILEK-family, and are held in perpetuity. These rights are maintained in the living memory of the residents of each longhouse. Boundaries are indicated by landforms or trees, or are marked by planting a row of bamboo. Except for the land overshadowed by the eaves of the longhouse, there is no land to which a community holds rights. With the introduction of surveys and titles to land in the early 1900s, Iban who lived closer to government centers obtained titles to their land, under which rights of individual families to land could be verified. As a result of increased population and the commercialization of land, some Iban have bought land for investment and speculation.' [667] Both sons and daughters could inherit property: 'Male and female children share equally in rights to real and other property so long as they remain members of their natal BILEK. Children who move out of the BILEK at marriage or for any other reason receive a small portion of the family estate, and in theory relinquish all rights to family land. In fact, however, they retain the right to request land for farming at the annual meeting commencing the agricultural year.' [668] 'Typically the ownership of the bilik apartment passes from parents to children. It is rare, however, for married siblings to share the same bilik , and so the apartment usually goes to just one child and his or her spouse. The remaining brothers and sisters will then marry into other bilik -families, or else establish a new bilik on their own. As will be evident from this last statement, residence patterns following marriage may be either virilocal or uxorilocal, with no particular preference being given for either one form of the other. Nor is there any formal principle - such as a rule of primogeniture - to decide which individual in a group of siblings gets to inherit the bilik in which they were born.' [669] The Iban practiced both partible and nonpartible inheritance. Nonpartible property was transmitted within senior lineages attached to a continuous longhouse community: 'It is one of the axioms of Iban adat that the padi pun of a bilek is nonpartible. What then is the solution when a family sub-divides into two separate households? Briefly it is this: the senior section retains possession of the padi pun , while the seceding section is presented with one of the sangking , which is then elevated to become its padi pun . Here, clearly, we have a criterion of crucial importance for the study of the process of bilek family formation in Iban society. The senior section of a family is always definable by the fact that its padi pun was inherited as padi pun ; while the padi pun of a seceding section is always inherited as sangking . By studying the inheritance of padi pun and sangking , therefore, it is possible to establish the main line of a family, and the various offshoots from it which have been brought about by partition.' [670] 'A second non-partible object is the batu pemanggol , or ritual whetstone, which is the centre-piece of the rites that initiate the yearly farming cycle. Each bilek family possesses one of these stones which is cherished as a magical charm of most vital importance. A few Iban families, indeed, still have whetstones upon which human victims--captives taken in war--were once sacrificed. Such stones are called batu jaum , and are immeasurably valuable in Iban estimation. To divide a batu pemanggol would be to destroy it, and so, when partition takes place, it is always retained in the ancestral bilek . The seceding section, seeking an auspicious occasion, gathers a suitable-looking stone from the river bed. With a great show of solemnity, the new stone is touched on the old and then consecrated; tutelary spirits are invoked and offerings made, and finally a pig or cock is sacrificed and the blood allowed to run on the stone's surface. This stone then becomes the batu pemanggol of the seceding section.' [671] 'When partition occurs then, the senior section of the family always retains the ancestral sacred rice and ritual whetstone. It may also happen that a bilek possesses some other unique magical or ritual object and, if this be the case, this too is retained by the senior section. With these exceptions, however, all the other property of the bilek is partible, and its apportionment is in accord with the relative size and the composition of the two sections resulting from the partition, following the general rule that siblings are parceners.' [672] Residence was ambilocal: 'Now, as already remarked, among the Iban virilocal marriage and uxorilocal marriage are equally permissible, for in Iban culture there are no beliefs or values which result in either form of marriage being given any sort of special preference. However, in all cases of permanent marriage a definite choice between the two possibilities must in the end be made, for there is no longterm system of alternate residence. Often, it is true, a newly married couple will follow first one form of domicile and then the other before finally settling down. Marrying into another apartment means permanently departing from one's natal or adoptive bilek family, and it is almost always an occasion of stress and sorrow, particularly for the parents of the seceding son or daughter. Conflicts of interest very frequently arise, but if a marriage is to endure a compromise is always reached, and, sooner or later, the couple permanently adopt either virilocal or uxorilocal residence.' [673] 'Marriage then, is an event of great moment, and particularly for the spouse who is leaving his (or her) natal apartment. Out-marriage, as we have seen, involves a radical change in jural status. It is also an occasion of psychological stress for the out-marrying spouse, since she (or he) is, in a sense, abandoning her natal family. Thus, one informant remarked that out-marriage ( ngugi ka orang ) meant ‘the casting away of one's father and mother’ (‘ itong udah buai apai indai ’). However, about 75% of Iban marriages are within the kindred, and so the stresses of out-marriage are often allayed by the fact that the out-marrying spouse is entering the household of fairly close kin.' [674] Both patrifiliation and matrifiliation were common: 'Further, membership of his (or her) natal bilek confers upon a child inheritance rights over its properties and lands, and these rights are retained as long as the individual remains a resident member. Among the Iban, then, filiation is of a special kind, for it may be either to an individual's mother's bilek or to an individual's father's bilek, but not to both at the same time. Moreover, in practice, both types of filiation occur to an approximately equal extent. We are here confronted with a fundamental principle of the Iban family system.' [675] Given the practice of ambilocal residence, inheritance rights were thus determined by residence rather than gender: 'However, should a man, upon marriage, permanently leave his natal bilek , he thereby relinquishes his parcenary rights over its estate, but acquires rights in the bilek into which he marries and settles down. The same applies to a woman who marries out of her natal apartment. An affine, then, possesses parcenary rights within the bilek of which he (or she) is a resident member.' [676] '10. Within the bilek family siblings have equivalent rights; in other words, they are parceners or co-heirs. If a sibling marries out he thereby relinquishes rights of inheritance in his natal bilek family, but acquires rights in the bilek family into which he marries. This rule applies equally to men and to women. When divorce occurs an individual returns to his or her natal bilek family and resumes rights there; but widows and widowers do not return to their natal bilek families. Thus, an analysis of 52 cases showed that there were 26 widows or widowers living as members of their natal bilek families, and 26 who were living in bilek families of which they were members by right of marriage and local residence.' [677] 'In accordance with custom, an Iban who marries into another longhouse and joins his or her spouse's family is no longer entitled to inherit ancestral lands left behind in the former longhouse area. If such an individual has no siblings living in his or her original family bilek , these lands are left under the guardianship of the Tuai Rumah, who has authority to allow other members of the longhouse to make use of them until one of the former owner's heirs can re-establish the ancestral bilek and reclaim its lands. Only lands which are officially titled can be claimed wherever the owner lives in the country; otherwise rights of use are contigent upon the family's continual residence within the longhouse where the land is located. This means that if an Iban migrates from one river to another, he will automatically loose rights to all of his temuda lands which have no official title. If he has no sibling living in the village these lands will become available for use by the people of the longhouse he has left and are subject to reapportionment by the Tuai Rumah.' [678] Both sons and daughters could initiate partition and out-marriage: '2. The bilek , with the exception of certain ritual objects, is a partible estate; and a sibling who remains in his (or her) natal bilek has the right to claim a proportionate share of the family inheritance, and set up a separate domestic unit. This is a common happening. Indeed, when two elementary families emerge [Page 8] within a bilek, partition always follows in due course. This precludes the development of joint or extended families, and nowhere in Sarawak did I encounter siblings--married and having adult children of their own--who were still living together as members of the same bilek. Again, my observations showed that partition always involves the break-up of a sibling group. When partition occurs one sibling and his (or her) family secedes from the ancestral bilek to found a new and independent household. Furthermore, this sibling is just as likely to be a man as a woman; thus, an analysis of 34 cases of partition showed that 17 founders of seceding families were males, while 17 were females. A fundamental feature of partition is that each part--after partition has occurred--is an autonomous unit in its own right, and not merely a constituent part of some wider corporate group. The partition of bilek families as it occurs in Iban society is thus a different process from segmentation as it occurs in societies based on unilineal principles.' [679] Property could also be transferred to adopted children: 'If a man and his wife, after many years of marriage, are certain that they will have no child of their own, they are likely to adopt a child in order that he or she may inherit their property after they have passed away and perpetuate their bilek family. Most couples prefer to adopt a child of their closest relatives, such as a nephew or a niece. However, if their close relatives have no child whom they are willing or able to give in adoption, the couple may adopt the child of a distant cousin or an unrelated friend.' [680] 'In order to make an adoption legal, the adopters must hold a formal ceremony called the Gawai Biru-iru, in which they publicly announce in the presences of guests, including at least two Tuai Rumah or a Penghulu, and their relatives who, otherwise, would inherit their property if they were to die childless, that the child is hereby adopted to be their own. By this proclamation the child is acknowledged as their legal heir with identical rights of inheritance, as if he or she were the couple's sole natural child. In future, if any argument arises over the disposal of the couple's property, the [Page 79] Tuai Rumah or Penghulu who were present at the Gawai Biru-iru, are responsible for safeguarding the rights of the adopted child in court. These rights, are identical whether the child is male or female.' [681] 'We have now seen that the Iban bilek family is an autonomous, corporate group, all the resident members of which--natal, adopted and affinal--hold rights over its estate. As the Iban themselves put it: ‘Whoever stands by the bilek (i.e. remains a resident member), he (or she) possesses the belongings, possesses the valuables’ (‘ Sapa tan ka bilek, iya empu utai, empu keresa ’). This was an utterance made at Rumah Nyala in 1950 during the formal discussion of the conditions which were to govern the adoption of an infant boy, and it was made by one of the men of the adopting family. It was a public pledge that as long as the adopted child elected to remain resident in their apartment he would possess identical rights of inheritance with the other members of the family. This fundamental principle of inheritance was reiterated many times during the course of the discussion--as it always is on such occasions. finally, to clinch the matter, another of the adopting party put it even more trenclantly by abruptly asserting: ‘Whoever stands by the bilek , even be he a Kayan, a Bukitan, a Punan, an Ukit, it matters not, he is the one who inherits the property’ (‘ Sapa tan ka bilek, Kayan, Pakatan, Punan, Ukit, enda iboh, tya empu keresa ’) Now, the Kayans, the Bukitans, the Punans and the Ukits are neighbouring tribes of the Rejang headwaters; all are alien, and the Kayans and Ukits, in particular, are the bitter traditional enemies of the Iban. When this is realized, the force of the utterance just quoted will be appreciated. It affirms that even an enemy and an alien, should he come to live in an Iban bilek , would, if he maintained his residence, hold equal rights of inheritance with the other members of the family. For Iban ears there could be no more emphatic avowal than this of the principle we have been considering.' [682] In-marrying affines of either sex became full members of their spouse's longhouse community: 'The position of the natal members of a bilek family in regard to inheritance is clear, for their prerogative depends on direct descent. Furthermore, as we have seen, an adopted child has conferred upon him exactly the same rights. But what of an affine whose membership dates only from the time of his (or her) marriage? By way of explanation let us consider the case of a man who marries out of his natal bilek . When such a man decides upon uxorilocal residence, and when, in the course of time, it becomes evident to all concerned that this marriage will be a lasting one, he receives from his natal bilek family a form of personal inheritance called pemai . The amount of pemai given to an out-marrying member varies considerably from case to case, for it depends largely on the degree to which the other senior members of the bilek family approve of the marriage that has been contracted. Cases do occur in which [Page 36] no pemai at all is given, while at the other extreme, planned marriages between members of wealthy families are often marked by a show of ostentation. Very commonly the pemai consists of a Chinese jar or a bronze gong, and of various smaller articles such as plates and bowls.' [683] 'The giving of this pemai is an event of signal importance, for it constitutes the final fulfilling of a man's rights of inheritance as far as his natal bilek is concerned, and it further represents the formal termination of membership of his natal (or adoptive) bilek family. Henceforward, he is a full member of his wife's bilek . His pemai , or personal inheritance, becomes part of the estate of his wife's apartment, and all his energies are now devoted to the welfare of this new family; any valuables he may acquire (as, for example, on a bejalai , or journey) are the property-- meum et tuum --of this group. In other words, when a man marries out of his own apartment and into another, he has conferred upon him full jural membership of a new corporate group, with all its attendant privileges and obligations. And the same, of course, applies to a woman.' [684] Freeman provides a general summary of the ineritance system: 'Having briefly described the composition of the bilek family and the way in which its members are recruited, we may turn to an examination of the principles governing inheritance, for these, under the Iban system of filiation, are of particular significance. Let us begin by considering the position of the natal and adopted members of the family. As has already been stressed, children become members by right of birth of either their father's or their mother's bilek --but it is always one or the other. Thus, the children of a man practising uxorilocal residence are the members of their mother's natal bilek , and of this local group alone. They have no rights of inheritance within their father's natal bilek, of which they are not resident members. Similarly, the children of a woman practising virilocal residence are members of their father's local group, and have no rights of inheritance in their mother's natal bilek . Adopted children are members of the bilek into which they have been adopted, and of this bilek only.' [685] 'The general rule for both natural and adopted children is this: as long as they remain resident members of their own bilek family, sons and daughters possess full and equal rights of inheritance over the family estate. In other words, within a bilek siblings are parceners or co-heirs. There is thus recognition of neither primogeniture nor ultimogeniture, and no differentiation [Page 32] between the sexes, nor between natural and adopted children. Instead, in matters of inheritance, siblings are equals. Their equivalence is well expressed in the phrase: ‘ menyadi tampong pala ’ which the Iban use to describe them. These words, which have the literal meaning: ‘siblings whose heads are joined’, symbolize aptly the kind of relationship in which siblings stand. Another much-used phrase is: ‘ menyadi begulai pemai ’ meaning ‘siblings of common inheritance’.' [686] 'As long then, as an individual remains resident in a bilek , he (or she) is one of the group in which ownership and inheritance are vested. Indeed, it is the family as a whole that holds common tenure of the conglomeration of property and other rights which constitute ‘the bilek ’. In other words, the Iban bilek family is a corporation aggregate. Thus, no one of its members holds the right [Page 33] to disinherit another. In life the members of a bilek are parceners, and even in death each member is entitled to his share of the family estate--that last inheritance which he carries with him to the after-world. An elder looks to his children and to his grandchildren within the bilek family to care for him in his old age, and to perform conscientiously the elaborate mortuary rites which must accompany his passing from this world to the next. To the Iban these mortuary rites and the furnishing of grave goods are matters of supreme importance, and all the senior surviving members of the bilek family are expected to join in their faithful performance. As the Iban themselves phrase it: ‘As the mortuary rites are equally performed, so equally is the bilek estate inherited’ (‘ Enti blah ngelumbong, blah empu utai ’).' [687]
♠ Trusts ♣ absent ♥ We are unsure whether longhouse families constitute trust in our own sense of the term. We have assumed this is not the case.
♠ State expropriation ♣ present ♥ Unused lands reverted to the colonial government: 'The Brooke courts helped to reinforce the development of common farming land in the Second Division by adopting the principle that any land which had not been utilized for a specified period (including virgin land) reverted to the Government. For example, in Abang Embit [Page 20] and others v Penghulu Luta , an important case from the Paku, it was stated: “By published Gov't Orders, jungle of over 3 years growth on swamp and 7 years on hill land cannot be claimed by anyone, being the property of the State . . . [A]nyone wishing to fell same for the purpose of farming, may do so without the necessity for a permit” (Betong Court Book 1920:483). It is not clear to which Government Orders this statement refers, nor on what basis the 3 and 7 year limits were chosen (given that, for hill rice farming, 7 years is close to the absolute minimum fallow period required for sustained yield). Nevertheless, the use of these guidelines by the courts had the effect of strengthening the trend towards greater community control over the disposal of farming land, as in practice the designated “State land” differed little from the common land described by Phillips.' [688]
♠ Non-state expropriation ♣ absent ♥

Equity[edit]

Sex Class and Race[edit]

Marriage

♠ Monogamy ♣ present ♥ eHRAF provides a general description of the marriage and kinship systems: 'The BILEK-family is an autonomous unit, able to join with other units of a longhouse or to detach itself. Iban become members of a family through birth, adoption, marriage, or incorporation. The family is responsible for construction of its own unit, production of its own food, and management of its own affairs. In a sample of 1,051 families, 60 percent were comprised of parents and children, 40 percent included grandparents. The family is a kin-based, corporate group, holding in trust land, sacred rice, sacred charms, ritual formulas, taboos, and heirloom gongs and jars. Traditionally, one son or daughter has remained in the BILEK to ensure continuity over time. With urban migration, and mail service making possible postal remittances, an increasing number of parents have no adult child residing in the BILEK with them.' [689] 'Preferred and proscribed marriages are commonly recognized. Though parents prefer to arrange their children's marriages, especially educated young people would rather choose their own mates. Marriage is preferably with a person between the degree of first and fifth cousin. Distinctions are made between parallel and cross cousins; marriages between the former are avoided. Although most Iban marriages are monogamous, isolated instances of sororal and nonsororal polygyny occur. Marriage between a man and a woman who are related as member of adjacent generations is not approved, but propitiatory rites can be performed if, for example, an aunt and nephew insist on marrying. Marriage within the kin group is preferred in order to protect property rights, and to avoid union with a descendant of slaves or a person of ill fortune. Residence is ambilocal or neolocal. Divorce may be initiated by either partner and, if with mutual consent, is relatively easy.' [690] According to Freeman, monogamy was the norm: 'Finally, let me comment briefly on the most important affinal relationship of all : that of husband and wife. The conjugal tie, as we have already seen, is basic to the structure of the bilek family, and of crucial significance to the kinship system as a whole. Monogamy is reflected in the fact that the terms laki (husband) and bini (wife) can be applied to only one person at a time. Between husband and wife there is no clearly structured pattern of superordination-subordination; although there is a sharply demarcated sexual division of labour, and a differentiation of ritual and other roles, a husband and wife, in their family life, are equals. Again, marriage among the Iban rests not on status, class, clan membership, or any other kind of prescriptive structural consideration but on the affection and regard which a husband and wife have for one another. It is understandable, therefore, that the bond between husband and wife, in the opinion of the Iban is, ideally, closer than that between siblings.' [691] Conjugal relations were relatively egalitarian: 'Among the Dyaks no man has more than one wife. Polygamy is considered very displeasing to the gods, and [Page 129] conjugal affection is rare among the Dyaks. On the contrary, a great deal of it exists, and the men very often love their wives and think a great deal of their opinion. They will not decide upon any important course of action without consulting them. Where there are children, the husbands very often help their wives in doing more than their share of the man's work, and I have often seen the men nursing and fondling their naked babies when the mothers were busy.' [692] Residence was ambilocal: 'Now, as already remarked, among the Iban virilocal marriage and uxorilocal marriage are equally permissible, for in Iban culture there are no beliefs or values which result in either form of marriage being given any sort of special preference. However, in all cases of permanent marriage a definite choice between the two possibilities must in the end be made, for there is no longterm system of alternate residence. Often, it is true, a newly married couple will follow first one form of domicile and then the other before finally settling down. Marrying into another apartment means permanently departing from one's natal or adoptive bilek family, and it is almost always an occasion of stress and sorrow, particularly for the parents of the seceding son or daughter. Conflicts of interest very frequently arise, but if a marriage is to endure a compromise is always reached, and, sooner or later, the couple permanently adopt either virilocal or uxorilocal residence.' [693] 'Marriage then, is an event of great moment, and particularly for the spouse who is leaving his (or her) natal apartment. Out-marriage, as we have seen, involves a radical change in jural status. It is also an occasion of psychological stress for the out-marrying spouse, since she (or he) is, in a sense, abandoning her natal family. Thus, one informant remarked that out-marriage ( ngugi ka orang ) meant ‘the casting away of one's father and mother’ (‘ itong udah buai apai indai ’). However, about 75% of Iban marriages are within the kindred, and so the stresses of out-marriage are often allayed by the fact that the out-marrying spouse is entering the household of fairly close kin.' [694] Combined with exogamy, this resulted in frequent in-marriage and out-marriage: 'We have now briefly examined recruitment by birth and recruitment by adoption. Full membership of a bilek family may also be attained by marrying into it. Marriage, indeed, is a crucial determinant of bilek family membership. As already remarked, the Iban are a rigorously monogamous people, and [Page 30] further, the Iban bilek family--by adat --is a strictly exogamous unit. Iban custom does ordinarily permit the marriage of first cousins ( petunggal diri menyadi ), but incest rules prescribe that marriage between first cousins who are resident members of the same bilek should never take place. From this fact that marriage never occurs within the confines of a single bilek family it follows that every marriage necessitates one of the partners leaving his or her natal or adoptive bilek .' [695] The relative frequency of outmarriage and partition was associated with the size of the sibling group: 'A special problem with which one has to deal in attempting to explain the working of the Iban family system is the differential incidence of out-marriage and partition. An obvious way of coping with this question is to examine a series of different sibling groups and to determine, for each of them, the relative incidence of outmarriage, adoption out of the bilek , and bilek partition. One necessary condition for a survey of this kind is that all the sibling groups considered should have reached a stage at which all of the processes to be examined had reached a state of completion. Accordingly, I extracted from my collection of genealogies for R. Nyala, R. Sibat and R. Tungku, all the available cases of this kind. This gave me ninety-eight sibling groups in all--ranging in size from one to nine members. For all of these ninety-eight groups I noted the instances of out-marriage, adoption out, and partition--where they occurred--and then tabulated the results. The results for out-marriage and partition are tabulated in the diagram opposite. Along the horizontal axis of the graph the ninety-eight sibling groups of the sample are arranged in order of size from one to nine; and along the vertical axis frequencies are shown as percentages, cases of out-marriage, as they occurred, as a percentage of all possible cases; cases of partition, as they occurred, as percentage of the total number of cases of partition which might have occurred.' [696] 'The diagram can be summarized verbally, as follows: Size of sibling group ref.: out-marriage and partition: 1: Partition never occurs; out-marriage is exceedingly rare (5% of cases); (i.e. sole heir always remains in natal bilek , except in highly rare and unusual circumstances). 2: Out-marriage and partition about equal (e.g. 47%:44%). 3: Out-marriage slightly more common than partition (e.g. 53%:37%). 4: Out-marriage about twice as common as partition (e.g. 66%:29%). 5: Out-marriage remains markedly more common than partition (e.g. about twice as common).' [697] 'Let us now glance at the phenomenon of out-marriage. We can, I think, on the evidence from our sample of ninety-eight sibling groups, make a generalization something of this kind: The incidence of marriage out of natal bilek families (i.e. into other bilek families) exhibits a slight tendency to progressive increase as the size of sibling groups (in bilek families) progressively increases.' [698] '(E.g. from an average incidence of 48% in the case of sibling groups of two members to an average incidence of 60% in the cases of sibling groups of five and over.) (1) As a sibling group increases in numbers the potential share of any one individual of the bilek estate decreases. (E.g. sole heir inherits whole of estate, two children inherit half each, three one-third each, and so on.) This means that as a sibling group increases in size it becomes increasingly less ‘worth while’ for any member of the group to remain in his natal bilek , with the intention of claiming his share of the bilek estate. In other words, it is more ‘worth while’ (i.e. in his material, social and other interests) for any member of a large sibling group to marry out of his natal bilek and into another with only one or two members in its sibling group. He thus tends to inherit more property; and to acquire, as a result of this, greater social and ritual standing and influence. (2) The male members of large sibling groups are presented with greater opportunities for going on bejalai because their services in farming are not so vitally [Page 50] required. This presents them with greater opportunities for meeting nubile females and settling down in other areas. The inducement for such males to return to a large bilek family is not so great.' [699] '(3) All Iban apartments are of about the same size. As a large family grows up living in this confined space becomes increasingly uncongenial. For members of large families out-marriage is the easiest avenue of escape. (Partition is a much more difficult operation, for other members of the sibling group may offer opposition, etc.) (4) The aim of most Iban men and women is to possess a bilek of their own. This confers the independence which is dear to every Iban's heart. Out-marriage is an easier avenue to this independence than partition.' [700] 'The incidence of partition exhibits a tendency to progressive decrease as the size of sibling groups progressively increases. (E.g. from an average incidence of 44% in the case of sibling groups of two to three members to an average incidence of 21% in the case of sibling groups of five and over.) These, in general, are the converse of what has been said for out-marriage. When a sibling group is small in size (two to three members) the share of the family estate available to a sibling is sufficiently large (i.e. one-half to one-third) to provide strong inducement. As a sibling group increases in size, however, the share available to a sibling desiring partition becomes progressively less, so offering less inducement towards partition. Because of this, out-marriage offers stronger inducements as the size of the sibling group increases. So the incidence of partition decreases and the incidence of out-marriage increases as the size of the sibling group increases.' [701] Howell provides a description of courtship and wedding practices: 'When a young man has been successful in his wooing, and has made an alliance with a maiden, he leaves her a ring as a pledge of his betrothal to her. After visiting her for some little time and finding her faithful to him, he asks for his parent's consent to marry. If his parents have no objection to his choice they go to see the girl's parents and take a cup with them to ask for their daughter. If the girl's parents approve of the contract they accept the cup. The cup is the final pledge of a marriage contract between the two parties. They then fix the day when the bride is to be fetched.' [702] 'The marriage ceremony is very simple and is celebrated in the bride's house. It consists of splitting a pinang or areca nut into seven pieces and these are put on a brass tray with seven serih leaves, seven pieces of gambier and seven small lumps of lime. All the friends and relations gather round the tray and eat it's contents, at the same time talking over the binding nature of the marriage contract. It is to this effect. If a man leaves or puts away his wife unless she commits adultery or on account of an unlucky dream, or a bad omen. or inhospitality to stranger, or bad temper, he will be fined according to the law laid down by their forefathers. Similar things are also said about the woman. The binding nature of a Dyak marriage in itself is good, if it be carried out. There are other rules connected with marriage among Dyaks, such as, if the wife in the natural course of things becomes blind, or diseased, and the husband puts her away, he must incur a heavy fine. 8imilar rules also are binding on the wife.' [703] Low claims that permarital sexual relations were common in some groups: 'Though from their friendly intercourse with the Malays they have adopted some of the customs, and have borrowed considerably from the language of that [Page 195] people, they have not introduced polygamy, or, with the exception of slavery, any other of their reprehensible practices. The ceremony of marriage, as far as I have learnt, is very simple, and consists merely in the persons, who have previously agreed upon the point, living together, and a feast being made on the occasion to which all who choose may repair. Their marriage feasts, like all the others, usually end in the whole of the persons assembled becoming intoxicated with a fermented beverage which they make from rice, and which they affirm they were taught by the Chinese.
